captions.text:
I imagine that working for EA must be rather
like living with a toddler, drunk person or
president of the United States.
Imagine Bioware&#39;s plight.

&quot;Well now that you&#39;ve spent all that money
getting the Star Wars license, we did make

Knights of the Old Republic back in the day,
so perhaps we could-&quot; &quot;NO HATE STAR WARS.
Star Wars is boring.
Cancel all the Star Wars.
I want that.&quot;
&quot;You want what?&quot;
&quot;I WANT THAT.&quot;
&quot;What, Destiny?&quot;
&quot;Yes.

I want thing that looks like Halo with somehow
even less personality.&quot;

&quot;Well you can&#39;t have Destiny, it&#39;s owned by
Activision-Blizzard-&quot; &quot;I WAA MAA WAA-&quot; &quot;Alright,

alright, I suppose we could make something
that&#39;s a lot like Destiny.

I mean, mindless online only looty shooties
aren&#39;t really our thing, we&#39;re more about

character-based role-playing... oh dear, please
stop holding your breath, EA, look, we made
our own version of Destiny, it&#39;s called Anthem.&quot;
&quot;Eurgh I hate it.
You&#39;re all fired.
Why didn&#39;t you make a Star Wars game?&quot;

I wouldn&#39;t take it personally, Bioware, this
is what EA does.

Buy a developer, force them to rip off something
popular and outside their comfort zone, blame

them for the inevitable failure, shut them
down, buy themselves a new ball pit.
It&#39;s just how they run their business.

Like some bizarre combination of hazing ritual
and murder spree.

If Anthem is aping Destiny then it&#39;s got the
approach to story down pat.

The first thing it does is start throwing
capitalized words at me like a glossary with

gastroenteritis - the Shapers created the
Anthem that is causing Cataclysms and Freelancers

Cyphers Sentinels Javelins Dominion Cenotaph
- well shit, Bioware, I thought I knew what
all those words meant.
In the end I wouldn&#39;t worry about it.

This is the Destiny and indeed the Halo thing
where the story is about 90% setting and 10%
plot.

I&#39;m sure the writers have done a lot of world
building while doodling on the backs of their

exercise books, but all that you actually
need to know is humans yay, everyone else

boo, and there&#39;s your common or garden all
powerful ancient artefact somewhere that you

have to stop the bad guys getting to and making
whoosh crikey lasers come out of which would
presumably be bad.

But let&#39;s not gloss over the story because
Anthem is a game of two parts that are forced

to live together in a state of open hostility,
like Israel and Palestine, although Israel

and Palestine have never tried to flog loot
boxes to Lebanon.

On one side you have Story Land, where all
the story happens, a happy community hub roughly

the size of an average suburban strip mall,
packed with smiling NPCs with big golden speech

bubbles over their heads that seem to say
&quot;Please click, I used up three exercise books
working this character out.&quot;

And literally walled off from that is Gameplay
Land, a huge beautiful expanse of bugger all

which you venture into after putting on your
Power Rangers romper suit, confront whichever

of the four or five enemy factions drew the
short straw today and create enough new widows

and orphans to make up, say, a standard philharmonic
orchestra.

And diplomatic relations between the lands
of Story and Gameplay seem to be poor.

For example, Story Land just doesn&#39;t acknowledge
multiplayer at all.

As far as its concerned, you are a lone warrior
who is humanity&#39;s last best hope and if you&#39;re

curious to know why three other guys keep
popping out of your arse every time you leave,

then you&#39;ll have to find answers elsewhere,
it&#39;s busy writing more optional dialogues
for you to ignore.

Meanwhile, show up at Gameplay Land and ask
if it would be possible to play single player

and the game reacts like you sat down in an
expensive restaurant and ordered a bowl of
cornflakes.

You go to the privacy settings - once you
can find the fucking things &#39;cos this game

has a worse menu system than a McDonalds Drive-Thru
after a major earthquake, what is it with

ultra-AAA games having shitty interfaces these
days, is it the same principle by which Las

Vegas casinos are laid out to get you lost
and unable to glimpse the sun in the hope

that you get confused and accidentally drop
all your money - and your options are &quot;Public

match as God intended&quot; or &quot;Private match for
big stupid losers&quot;.

Then when you set it to private and try to
start solo a window pops up saying &quot;Ha ha

ha, sorry, someone&#39;s clearly made a dreadful
mistake, surely you don&#39;t actually want to
play a solo private match.

Just click here and we&#39;ll set it back to public
play so you can rejoin all the normal people.&quot;

But I didn&#39;t click that and then the tip on
the fucking loading screen was something about

how playing multiplayer earns more rewards
and doesn&#39;t make the little baby Jesus cry.
What the fuck is this, guys?
Am I on suicide watch?

I don&#39;t know why the multiplayer&#39;s being pushier
than the last high school virgin on their
prom date.
The game&#39;s perfectly playable solo.
Tedious, but playable.

Most of the missions are variations on &quot;go
to a place, press the button, depopulate another

orchestra&quot; but at least in single play you&#39;re
guaranteed to be the one participating in

the plot, and aren&#39;t racing three other guys
to be the one to activate the beacon, rescue

the prisoner, fluff the distemperate wildebeest
or whatever the story objective is.

And you&#39;ll also get to have a go at the ancient
puzzles that occasionally pop up in the course

of the dungeons, and they won&#39;t be instantly
solved by the one random dickhead on your

team who&#39;s done them before &#39;cos they&#39;re grinding
up their third character.

For you could release a game about tucking
frozen peas under your scrotum and there&#39;ll

still be at least one person weirdly obsessed
with being the best at it.

Story being the thing Bioware is good at - well,
I say good.

If I were writing their school report I&#39;d
say &quot;they certainly approach the subject with

enthusiasm&quot; - the gameplay clearly exists
on sufferance.

And yet, the main story is still surprisingly
short and padded out.

The bit where you can&#39;t continue the plot
until you complete a checklist of arbitrary
gameplay grinds springs to mind.
A very poorly explained checklist, at that.
&quot;Get five Multikills&quot;.
What the fuck&#39;s a Multikill, Anthem?
&quot;Well, what do you think it is?&quot;

Erm... killing more than two enemies with
one grenade?
&quot;Ooh, good guess.
Wrong, though.&quot;

Another objective is to heal three stricken
friendlies.

Welp, that&#39;s the solo players completely alienated,
catch you later, Anthem.

Then a little googling revealed that there
are some NPC friendlies fighting the enemy

in one spot of the freeroam map and you can
grind up your resurrects there.

Although with the AI being what it is I was
sitting on a hilltop for ages waiting for

the enemy to get their heads together long
enough to splatter one of the little bastards.

And then I&#39;d look up and see two other players
hovering like vultures.
&quot;Hey!
I saw them first!
Back off, Mr. Healy Stealy.&quot;
Do I need to go on?

I mean, the internet hive mind seems to have
already declared Anthem to be the thing we

all hate of the month, and for all my contrarian
instincts I can&#39;t disagree.
But don&#39;t hate Anthem, viewers.
Pity Anthem.

Pity Bioware, for Anthem is their cry for
help.

It&#39;s a grindy generic shooter that not even
jetpacks can save, but the brief trips to

Story Land for elaborately animated character
cutscenes hint at what Bioware would rather
have been making.

Sadly &#39;twas but the face of a tormented younger
brother briefly glimpsed before it disappears
again beneath the flabby buttocks of its sibling.

&quot;Please give us one more crack at Mass Effect,&quot;
it seems to say.

&quot;What if we let you have sex with the ship
this time?&quot;
